Texto: 
physical exam is unremarkable. 

labs:
hemoglobin/hematocrit: 13.0/38.0
wbc: 7.3
platelets: 291
sodium: 139
potassium: 3.9
chloride: 103
bicarbonate: 25.7
glucose: 103
creatinine: 0.3
bun: 16

c24:0 tetracosanoic acid (high) 101.96 
--reference range: 24.25 to 77.75 unit: umol/l 
c26:0 hexacocanoic acid (high) 2.81
--reference range: 0.17 to 0.73 unit: umol/l
c24:0/c22:0 (high) 1.86 
-- reference range: 0.64 to 1.02 
c26:0/c22:0 (high) 0.051 
--reference range: 0.003 to 0.015
treatment: current treatment modalities include dietary therapy involving a low-fat diet and consumption of lorenzo’s oil, lovastatin therapy, bone marrow transplants, and iv immunoglobulin therapy.

follow up: genetic counseling for family
head ct without iv contrast:

focal low-attenuation in the splenium of the corpus callosum, with associated vasogenic edema extending into the cerebral white matter bilaterally. lateral ventricles appear borderline enlarged, r>l

head mri without and with iv contrast:
there is a symmetric and confluent signal abnormality involving the  splenium of the corpus callosum, bilateral peritrigonal white  matter, and corticospinal tracts; hyper-intense on t2-weighted images and hypo-intense on t1 weighted images.  there is linear peripheral enhancment just beneath the leading edge of the abnormal areas including the peritrigonal white matter and corticospinal tracts; this intermediatezone enhancement is  typical of x-linked adrenal leukodystrophy. mild diffusion restriction  is also seen in an identical distribution to the linear enhancement,  which has also been described with x-linked ald and has been  attributed to active demyelination. on t2-weighted images, this thin  intermediate zone is about iso-intense to normal white matter, which also is a typical finding. no abnormalities are identified in  the frontal white matter. the ventricles appear normal in size and shape.
x-linked adrenoleukodystrophy
leukoencephalopathy
leukodystrophy
this is a 7 year old boy who presents to the children's ed with dizziness, ataxia, weakness, vomiting, and leg twitching. the patient had been at a wrestling match doing warm up exercises at the time of the onset of symptoms.  he has a history of tics and nystagmus
